docs.snippet: Royal Philips Electronics today joined a growing parade of companies announcing annual losses in the billions, in large part because of write-downs on the value of stakes in other businesses.     Philips said that it lost 3.2 billion euros ($3.4 b...
docs.lead_paragraph: Royal Philips Electronics today joined a growing parade of companies announcing annual losses in the billions, in large part because of write-downs on the value of stakes in other businesses. Philips said that it lost 3.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion) in 2002, a disastrous year in which its share price decreased by more than half. Almost half of the damage to earnings was done in the fourth quarter, when Philips lost 1.53 billion euros ($1.6 billion), 44 percent more than in the period in 2001.
docs.abstract: Royal Philips Electronics lost 3.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion) in 2002 and 1.53 billion euros ($1.6 billion) in fourth quarter; sales in 2002 were 32 billion euros ($34 billion), 2 percent decline from 2001; photo of chief executive Gerard J Kleisterlee (M)

headline.main: Philips Electronics Lost $3.4 Billion Last Year

docs.snippet: Carolina Herrera said her collection was about cocktail dressing, but it was Oscar de la Renta who provided the shaker, serving up the meanest blend of wit and chic in a while.    Mr. de la Renta made it look easy -- and anybody can say that, but ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Carolina Herrera said her collection was about cocktail dressing, but it was Oscar de la Renta who provided the shaker, serving up the meanest blend of wit and chic in a while. Mr. de la Renta made it look easy -- and anybody can say that, but doing it is another matter. This is a moment when nothing can look too ostentatious, at least in public, and Mr. de la Renta wisely took the measure of the times, opening with dark brown suede gaucho pants over boots and a tea-cozy of a cape in burgundy cashmere. There were cropped sable vests and an alligator mini, too; but he treated everything as if it were just bar gin. Mr. de la Renta has been around enough women who knew how to look great and live well on a dime (even though they usually wound up with a million). And their secret was that they didn't try too hard. They didn't give a damn.
docs.abstract: Cathy Horyn reviews collections by Carolina Herrera and Oscar de la Renta; photos (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; Two Ways to Say Glamour: De la Renta and Herrera

docs.snippet: The latest radar on the proposed lifestyle magazine Radar is that it will be aimed ''at 29-year-olds as interested in Iraq as they are in Jennifer Lopez,'' its editor, Maer Roshan, told Women's Wear Daily. In other words, it will be a fashion maga...
docs.lead_paragraph: The latest radar on the proposed lifestyle magazine Radar is that it will be aimed ''at 29-year-olds as interested in Iraq as they are in Jennifer Lopez,'' its editor, Maer Roshan, told Women's Wear Daily. In other words, it will be a fashion magazine. Fashion is precisely the sort of fungible nexus where one can imagine encountering ''Iraq; impending war on,'' filed alongside ''Iraq; camouflage inspirations for spring!'' In what other setting but the newly politicized world of fashion is one likely to meet Sylvia Miles, the actress and ubiquitous scene presence, ranting about how currency markets profit from military buildup, while models strut a runway clad in evening wraps made from sock monkeys, as happened at the Liz Collins show on Sunday? Where else will one meet models who earn $2,500 for 10 minutes of work, talking about the evils of globalization? When, except during Fashion Week, is one apt to hear the loaded words ''conflict diamonds'' spoken in the velvety hush of Tiffany's Fifth Avenue store?
docs.abstract: Guy Trebay Fashion Diary comments on ubiquitous use of animal pelts at 2003 fashion show and reaction by organization People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals; photo (M)

headline.main: Reality Pokes Its Nose Into the Tents

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PEOPLE FOR THE ETHICAL TREATMENT OF ANIMALS

docs.snippet: Rarely does Hollywood-style glamour spill into this suburban Los Angeles enclave. But as the animation industry's elite gathered here recently at the Alex Theater to toast their favorite films of 2002, champagne glasses were clinking. Or was it th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Rarely does Hollywood-style glamour spill into this suburban Los Angeles enclave. But as the animation industry's elite gathered here recently at the Alex Theater to toast their favorite films of 2002, champagne glasses were clinking. Or was it the sound of jagged nerves? These are anxious times for film animators, whose business is being roiled by layoffs, new technology and tension between the industry's longtime leader, the Walt Disney Company, and its upstart partner, Pixar Animation Studios.
docs.abstract: Advent of computer animation is roiling industry, eliminating jobs -- 750 at Walt Disney Co alone -- and creating tension between Disney and its up partner, Pixar Animations Studios; almost every animated movie being considered for Oscar nomination this year was either purely computer-generated or used mixture of traditional and computer approaches; many industry people expect Disney to play lesser role in any new order, not only because of more competition, including DreamWorks, Sony and Viacom, but also because of loss of creative spark; Steven P Jobs, chief executive of Pixar, rarely speaks with Michael D Eisner, Disney chief executive, and has said that he is meeting with other studios in event that Disney does not agree to pact more favorable to Pixar in future; photos (M)

headline.main: As Animation Goes Digital, Disney Fights For Its Crown

docs.snippet: Shane Mosley wanted to negotiate a rematch with Oscar De La Hoya with his fists. But three rounds with Raul Marquez did nothing to improve his bargaining position.    Mosley's first fight at 154 pounds proved to be brief; the bout was stopped late...
docs.lead_paragraph: Shane Mosley wanted to negotiate a rematch with Oscar De La Hoya with his fists. But three rounds with Raul Marquez did nothing to improve his bargaining position. Mosley's first fight at 154 pounds proved to be brief; the bout was stopped late in the third round Saturday night because of deep cuts over Marquez's eyes.
docs.abstract: Ten-round, nontitle bout between Shane Mosley and Raul Marquez is stopped late in third round because of cuts over Marquez's eyes and ruled no contest; photo (M)

headline.main: No Contest Gives Mosley Little to Build On

docs.snippet: Law enforcement authorities in New York City and New Jersey said yesterday that they had seized about $61 million worth of cocaine and arrested five members of a Mexican drug gang that used a house on a quiet suburban block in Madison, N.J., to st...
docs.lead_paragraph: Law enforcement authorities in New York City and New Jersey said yesterday that they had seized about $61 million worth of cocaine and arrested five members of a Mexican drug gang that used a house on a quiet suburban block in Madison, N.J., to store drugs. The seizure, described as the largest in Morris County, followed a lengthy investigation by the police on both sides of the Hudson River. It evolved in part from Operation Crack Down, in which the New York City police have focused on drug trafficking in Washington Heights and Upper Manhattan, forcing dealers and distributors to other bases of operation.
docs.abstract: Police in New York and New Jersey seize 675 kilograms of cocaine worth about $61 million and arrest five members of Mexican drug gang that used house in Madison, NJ, to store drugs; seizure is said to be largest in Morris County and follows lengthy investigation; neighbors in quiet, upscale Madison comment; photo (M)

headline.main: Cocaine Trove Filled House In New Jersey, Officials Say

docs.snippet: Fashion seems to go all day and all night, playing to distinct audiences like a 12-screen multiplex in Paramus. On Saturday night, Sean Combs's $2 million electronic stimulation show didn't get started until after 9 o'clock, and there were still a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fashion seems to go all day and all night, playing to distinct audiences like a 12-screen multiplex in Paramus. On Saturday night, Sean Combs's $2 million electronic stimulation show didn't get started until after 9 o'clock, and there were still another show and a party to see, if one cared to. Yesterday, the whole thing started up again at 9 a.m. and would stretch into the ''Sopranos'' hour, ending, at least in one quarter of town, with Barry Diller's dinner at Indochine for his wife, Diane Von Furstenberg. Yet the challenge facing the fall 2003 collections -- and to a larger extent, the $142 billion fashion industry -- isn't how to get to all the shows scheduled between now and Friday night. After all, nobody expects to see everything. The problem is how to locate the core when fashion has exploded into 1,000 tiny particles of style.
docs.abstract: Cathy Horyn overview of 2003 fall collections shown in New York notes that industry has become diffuse, rather than relying on several big names; photos (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; Little-Known Stars Jazz Up the Opening Act

docs.snippet: To my mind, the Academy Awards have always deserved the status of a national holiday, being as they are a cross between an atheist's Easter and New Year's Eve, complete with mortals rising to the firmament -- some from the dead (at least in terms ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To my mind, the Academy Awards have always deserved the status of a national holiday, being as they are a cross between an atheist's Easter and New Year's Eve, complete with mortals rising to the firmament -- some from the dead (at least in terms of career), some never to serve a useful function on earth again -- and a teeny few (Hanks and Spielberg come to mind) who seem to inhabit both realms. Whenever the date rolls around, it also brings the joy and angst of New Year's -- the anticipation of thrills in counterpoint to the dread of not having a date or a place to go, or of a festivity at your place. And then, if it's at your place, what to serve? Well, you no longer have to bother with the big event on March 23. The winners are just as unreliable aesthetically as those of the Golden Globes, the SAG Awards, the National Board of Review, the New York and Los Angeles Critics and all those Top 10 lists. How else do you explain ''Citizen Kane,'' ''Dr. Strangelove,'' ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and a dozen other nonwinners of Best Picture? Or Chaplin, Lubitsch, Kubrick, Hitchcock, Hawks, Garland, Buster Keaton, Arthur Penn, Cary Grant and Marilyn Monroe never winning (though some were given special awards)? Aside from the academy's well-known bias against comedy, it must be democracy.
docs.abstract: Jonathan Reynolds Food column suggests menu for Academy Award nomination breakfast party; recipes; photo (M)
